incorrect-term.message: Don't spell out. Use "API" to refer to the entire set of operations, types, inputs, and outputs for a service. Do not use to refer to specific operations within a specific API (for example, "the CreateLambdaFunction API" is incorrect; "the CreateLambdaFunction API operation" is correct.
Avoid where possible. Instead, use a 24-hour time format. Note that 24:00 is 12 A.M (midnight) and 12:00 is 12 P.M. (noon).
First use: access control list (ACL). Subsequent use: ACL.
First use: access control list (ACL). Subsequent use: ACL.
First use: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES). Subsequent use: AES.
First use: AWS account. Subsequent use: account.

Do not use "AWS hybrid cloud" or the "AWS public cloud." Use of the terms "hybrid," "hybrid architecture," "hybrid cloud," "public cloud," "private cloud," or "on-premises environment" may be approved, but those terms should NOT be used to describe AWS. For example, it is not approved to say "AWS hybrid cloud" or the "AWS public cloud" but you may describe how your solution enables a hybrid cloud architecture connecting AWS to an on-premises environment.

Do not use "AWS hybrid cloud" or the "AWS public cloud." Use of the terms "hybrid," "hybrid architecture," "hybrid cloud," "public cloud," "private cloud," or "on-premises environment" may be approved, but those terms should NOT be used to describe AWS. For example, it is not approved to say "AWS hybrid cloud" or the "AWS public cloud" but you may describe how your solution enables a hybrid cloud architecture connecting AWS to an on-premises environment.
Use backend as an adjective and noun. Don't use "back end" or "back-end."
Use backend as an adjective and noun. Don't use "back end" or "back-end."
Avoid when describing AWS products, solutions, and services.

Use "Private Beta" for private pre-GA releases (these are gated and under NDA, there is no public announcement). Use "Preview" for public pre-GA releases (publicly available by default). Use "(Private Beta)" or "(Preview)" on first use only, and on PDF title pages and top-level website pages only. Capitalize only as part of a service name: "Amazon RDS (Preview). This preview release...". For more information, see https://w.amazon.com/bin/view/Utility_Computing_Working_Backwards_Approval_Process/#HProperLaunchTerminology.
First use: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP). Subsequent use: BGP.
First use: binary log (binlog). Subsequent use: binlog.
First use: GNU Binary Utilities (binutils). Subsequent use: binutils.
Refers to the BMP file format. It is widely known and understood, so just use BMP.
First use: bits per second (bps). Subsequent use: bps.
First use: Bluetooth Low Energy (LE). Subsequent use: Bluetooth LE.
Don't use. Use "bold" as an adjective, such as "The characters in bold type indicate..."

Uppercase. Boolean values are true and false. Avoid using a Boolean value name at the beginning of a sentence or sentence fragment. For specific programming languages, follow the usage in the language.
First use: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP). Second use: BGP.
First use: bits per second (bps). Subsequent use: bps.
Hyphen and uppercase "SSH" (for example, "After you create your instance, you can easily connect to it using our browser-based SSH terminal.").
One word. A graphical device to point out, or "call out," something in a graphic or sample for the reader.
One word (no hyphen). A graphical device to point out, or "call out," something in a graphic or sample for the reader.
First use: capital expenditure (capex). Subsequent use: capex.
Don't spell out. All instances: CAPTCHA. Stands for "Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart."
First use: central processing unit (CPU). Subsequent use: CPU.
First use: certificates. Subsequent use: certs.
Don't use CGW. All instances: customer gateway.
One word in all instances: chaincode.
One word in all instances: ciphertext.
In most content, use the full name "Classic Load Balancer" (title case). On consoles, when space is limited (such as dropdown lists), it's acceptable to use the acronym "CLB" if the context is clear.
Do not use "colo" except in reference to the cloud computing company of that name.
Don't hyphenate, even when used as a modifier.
Use to describe any utilities or tools that come packaged with a service. Do not use as a synonym for the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI).
Conda is a common part of the Anaconda Python open source distribution. Anaconda is commonly used with big data and machine learning projects.
Include hyphen and capitalize "Region." For the DynamoDB feature "Cross-Region Replication," use title case and include hyphen.
For the DynamoDB feature "Cross-Region Replication," use title case and include hyphen.
Do not hyphenate ( to be parallel with AWS managed keys, policies etc (which must not be hyphenated).
First use: customer master key (CMK). Subsequent use: CMK.
Lowercase and don't hyphenate. Data stored in Amazon S3 or on Amazon EBS, Amazon RDS, or other AWS database services.
Lowercase. Data stored in Amazon S3 or on Amazon EBS, Amazon RDS, or other AWS database services.
Lowercase and two words. Exception: SQL Server 2008 R2 Datacenter version.
Lowercase and two words. Exception: SQL Server 2008 R2 Datacenter version.
Lowercase and no hyphens. Use instead of "data in flight" for data network traffic between clients and servers and among servers.
Lowercase and no hyphens. Use instead of "data in flight" for data network traffic between clients and servers and among servers.
First use: data security standards (DSS). Subsequent use: DSS.
Use two words and lowercase. Exception: DataNode (Hadoop term).
Do not specify daylight saving time, which refers to clock settings within a time zone at specific times of the year.
Do not specify daylight saving time, which refers to clock settings within a time zone at specific times of the year.
Used in RDS as an adjective, to distinguish RDS resource types. For example:
First use: distributed denial of service (DDoS). Subsequent use: DDoS.
For EC2, use "Dedicated Host" (capitalized by request of the product team).
For EC2, use "Dedicated Instance" (capitalized by request of the product team).
For EC2, use "Dedicated Reserved Instance" (capitalized by request of the product team).

Avoid. Instead, specify exactly what the change means: Are you halting technical support? Removing a download link? No longer updating a service, script, or other product? Details will help make your meaning clear. Consider using a two-stage process: a) An announcement explaining that support or availability of a product or feature is ending (include the month and year when access or support will no longer be available), and b) a followup notice or revision of the original announcement to indicate the change has occurred, including the date.
All instances: DevOps. Development Operations (as in two departments combined).
All instances: DevOps. Development and Operations (as in two departments combined).
All instances: DevSecOps. Development , Security, and Operations (as in three departments combined).
First use: digital rights management (DRM). Subsequent use: DRM.
Incorrect. Use "disassociate" in reference to disassociating an ACM certificate. Do not use dissociate.
First use: disaster recovery (DR). Subsequent use: DR.
First use: disaster recovery (DR). Subsequent use: DR.
First use: DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM). Subsequent use: DKIM.

incorrect-term.suggestion: join the instance to the domain
incorrect-term.message: Do not use. Rewrite to include the object, "Join the instance to the domain....
Do not use. Use Elastic IP address instead.
Do not use. Use Elastic IP address instead.
Do not use "Elastic IP." Use Elastic IP address instead.
First use: Elastic Network Adapter (ENA). Subsequent use: ENA.
First use: elastic network interface. Subsequent use: network interface.
Do not use. First use: elastic network interface. Subsequent use: network interface.

Do not hyphenate. Use "email" as a singular noun or adjective to refer to the collective concept, and use "message" or "mail" for individual items. Use "send email" as the verb form. Do not use "emails" (collective noun); use "email messages" instead.

Do not hyphenate. Use "email" as a singular noun or adjective to refer to the collective concept, and use "message" or "mail" for individual items. Use "send email" as the verb form. Do not use "emails" (collective noun); use "email messages" instead.
Avoid. Use the simpler term "user" in most cases except when necessary to distinguish different levels of users (such as an organization's customers, or administrators vs. end users).
Avoid. Use the simpler term "user" in most cases except when necessary to distinguish different levels of users (such as an organization's customers, or administrators vs. end users).

Avoid when describing AWS products, solutions, and services. Suggested alternatives include: enable, facilitate, verify, provide, offer, warrant, certify, discontinue, validate, promote, or achieve. "Achieve" is a good option, especially when coupled with "help." "Make sure" can be used sparingly in general text, but not in reference to an AWS product or service, and only in situations where there aren't any stronger alternatives.
Use the AWSDOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET1, AWSDOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET2, etc. entities. Don't use examplebucket, which is an existing bucket that is owned by an AWS customer.

Don't use in place of resource-level permissions. Use when referring to using condition keys to finely control access to specific resources. For example, using condition keys in DynamoDB to provide access to individual data items in a specific table.

Don't use in place of resource-level permissions. Use when referring to using condition keys to finely control access to specific resources. For example, using condition keys in DynamoDB to provide access to individual data items in a specific table.
Use FQDN in most cases. On first use, use the long form: fully qualified domain name (FQDN). Use "Extensible Markup Language" alone only as needed to prevent confusion.
First use: gibibyte (GiB). Subsequent use: GiB.
First use: gibibyte (GiB). Subsequent use: GiB.
Greenwich Mean Time (archaic). Use UTC instead.
Do not hyphenate. First use: hard disk drive (HDD). Subsequent use: HDD.
First use: hard disk drive (HDD). Subsequent use: HDD.
One word and do not hyphenate.
First use: hardware virtual machine (HVM). Subsequent use: HVM.
First use: Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC). Subsequent use: HMAC.
Do not use. Use "Hello World" instead.
Do not use. Use "Hello World" instead.
Do not use. Use "Hello World" instead.
Do not use. Use "Hello World" instead.
First use: high availability (HA). Subsequent use: HA.
First use: high performance computing (HPC). Subsequent use: HPC.
Do not use. Use "enter" or "press" instead.
Do not use. Use "search results" or "customer page views" or something more specific.
One word in all instances: hostname.
Don't use in reference to holding a pointer or finger over a screen object. Use "pause on."
First use: Human Intelligence Task (HIT). Subsequent use: HIT.
First use: infrastructure as a service (IaaS). Subsequent use: IaaS.
First use: infrastructure as a service (IaaS). Subsequent use: IaaS.
First use: infrastructure as code (IaC). Subsequent use: IaC.
When referring to AWS Marketplace sellers, features, products, or benefits, you must use the phrasing "in" AWS Marketplace, not "on" AWS Marketplace.
First use: independent software vendor (ISV). Subsequent use: ISV.
Do not use. Use "open standards" instead.
First use: Information Security Management System (ISMS). Subsequent use: ISMS.
Use I/O in most cases. Use "input/output" only as needed to prevent confusion.
First use: input/output operations per second (IOPS). Subsequent use: IOPS.
Use "install in" for a folder, directory, or path. Use "install on" for a disk or drive or instance.
Use "install in" for a folder, directory, or path. Use "install on" for a disk or drive or instance.
Do not use in documentation. Do not use the term 3rd-party when referring to sellers in AWS Marketplace. Instead, use "independent software vendor (ISV) (preferred)" or "software sellers."

FIrst use: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON). Subsequent use: JSON. In general, use as an adjective (for example, "JSON file"). Okay to use as a noun on subsequent use (for example, "edit the JSON..."). Follow the same usage as XML or HTML.
First use: message authentication code (MAC). Subsequent use: MAC.
In most caes, use mult-factor authentication (MFA) on first use and MFA thereafter.
First use: Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME). Subsequent use: MIME.
Do not abbreviate as NGW. Use lowercase "gateway" for the type of NAT device, title case for the AWS managed service that controls NAT gateway resources.

incorrect-term.match: national institute of standards and technology
incorrect-term.suggestion: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
incorrect-term.message: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), NIST
First use: network access control list (network ACL). Subsequent use: network ACL.
First use: network access control list (network ACL). Subsequent use: network ACL.
First use: network address translation (NAT). Subsequent use: NAT.

incorrect-term.match: network address translation and protocol translation
incorrect-term.suggestion: Network Address Translation and Protocol Translation (NAT-PT)
incorrect-term.message: First use: Network Address Translation and Protocol Translation (NAT-PT). Subsequent use: NAT-PT.
First use: network interface (NIC). Subsequent use: NIC.
In most content, use the full name. On the consoles, when space is limited (such as dropdown lists), it's acceptable to use the NLB acronym if the context is clear.
Do not abbreviate as NGW. Use lowercase "gateway" for the type of NAT device, title case for the AWS managed service that controls NAT gateway resources.
In most content, use the full name. On the consoles, when space is limited (such as dropdown lists), it's acceptable to use the NLB acronym if the context is clear.
An open standard for authorizing access to server resources.
OpenID Connect. OIDC providers are entities in IAM that describe an identity provide that supports the OpenID Connect standard. OIDC-compatible providers include Google and Salesforce.
Do not use "on prem." Use on-premises as an adjective (for example, "an on-premises solution"). Or, use "on premises" to refer to the physical location.
Do not use "on premise." Use on-premises as an adjective (for example, "an on-premises solution"). Or, use "on premises" to refer to the physical location.
Do not use "on premise." Use on-premises as an adjective (for example, "an on-premises solution"). Or, use "on premises" to refer to the physical location.
Use as a predicate adjective. When the modifier comes before a noun, use "open-source.
operational expenditure. Spell out on first use.
Avoid when describing AWS products, solutions, and services. Suggested alternatives: more efficient, more effective, better, peak
First use: origin access identity (OAI). Subsequent use: OAI.
Avoid where possible. Use a 24-hour clock where necessary. Note that 12AM is midnight and 12PM is noon.
Do not capitalize or treat as part of the product name. Exception: Capitalize if it appears as part of product name in the UI.
Avoid where possible. Use a 24-hour clock where necessary. Note that 12AM is midnight and 12PM is noon.
Do not use as a reference to the Amazon Web Services website.
Capitalize the abbreviation but not precrypto officer.
As in, "This prerelease documentation is confidential and is provided under the terms of your nondisclosure agreement with Amazon Web Services.
Avoid except in "least privilege." Otherwise, use "permission."
First use: Real Time Messaging Protocol (RTMP). Subsequent use: RTMP.
Use "real-time" if the term qualifies a noun. Otherwise use "real time." Do not use "realtime."
Use "web service" to refer to a product whose primary purpose is to manipulate XML or JSON representations of web resources using a uniform set of stateless operations.
Use "web service" to refer to a product whose primary purpose is to manipulate XML or JSON representations of web resources using a uniform set of stateless operations.
First use: AWS account root user. Subsequent use: root user. Do not use "root account," "root identity," or "root credentials.
First use: AWS account root user. Subsequent use: root user.
First use: AWS account root user. Subsequent use: root user.
First use: AWS account root user. Subsequent use: root user.
First use: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). Subsequent use: SSL.
Lowercase. Security model wherein AWS and customers share responsibility for security.
First use: Microsoft SQL Server. Subsequent use: SQL Server. Pronounced 'sequel'. Uses 'a' instead of 'an' (a SQL Server instance).
First use: tebibyte (TiB). Subsequent use: TiB.
Two words, unless you need to match the UI text.
Only use in contrast with group policy or role policy. Use identity-based policy for all three. Do not use user-based policy.
First use: variable envelope return path (VERP). Subsequent use: VERP.
First use: virtual CPU. Subsequent use: vCPU.
First use: virtual interface or AWS public virtual interface. Subsequent use: VIF.
First use: virtual CPU. Subsequent use: vCPU.
First use: virtual machine (VM). Subsequent use: VM.
Always spell out as "virtual private gateway."
First use: web access control list (web ACL). Subsequent use: web ACL.
First use: web access control list (web ACL). Subsequent use: web ACL.
First use: Web Services Description Language (WSDL). Subsequent use: WSDL.

The words "wish" and "desire" are weak versions of "want"; don't use them. Do not confuse wants with needs. Use the term that is appropriate to the situation. The word "need" connotes a requirement or obligation; "want" indicates that you have an intent, but still a choice of valid actions.
Use "XML" in reference to the language. Use ".xml" in reference to files.
